text:
ANITA: Before I introduce
our guest speakers,

I'd like to do a quick overview
of the importance of water

and why companies, investors,
customers and governments should

be very concerned about
water and our water use.
First, let's review the basics.

Of all water on
earth, only about 1%

is usable by humans and
other living things,

meaning that there's
99% that's not.

That 1% of fresh water is stored
in our soil, groundwater, lakes,

rivers and streams,
swamps, such.

And if global warming increases,
this tiny limited resource
will be in high demand.

And with new greenhouse
gas reporting regulations,

governments, corporations,
and investors

will need to address
their water use

related to climate financial
risk, their net zero

targets, health issues as a
natural capital asset and more.

Some see this as a
daunting challenge,

but our Stanford
professor, Will Tarpeh,

who teaches the EIT 120,
the role of water and energy

for circular economies
sees wastewater

as an opportunity for
circular economy innovation

and the creation
of new businesses.

Well, with that
ground setting, I'm

excited for you to spend this
time with professors Will Tarpeh
and Will Chueh.

To start, Professor
Tarpeh, would you

please describe
the R. Buckminster

Fuller quote you refer to
when describing what you do?
WILL TARPEH: Absolutely.
Thanks, Anita.

And thanks, everyone,
for joining today.

Yeah, there's this quote
from R. Buckminster Fuller.
I'll paraphrase it.

But in short, it has
to do with pollution.

We consider things
pollution because we're
ignorant of their value.

If we think about this
one chemical compound

and change where it is
and what it's around,

we might call it a product
rather than a pollutant.

So a perennial
example of this is

something like ammonia, which
is a common fertilizer component

and feeds over half
the world, arguably.

However, when ammonia is
present in wastewater,
we consider it a pollutant.

Ammonia hasn't changed anything
about itself, its bonds,
anything like that.

But simply by
re-situating where it is,

we can turn pollutants
into products.

So that motivates a lot of
the work we do in my group,

and that's featured
in the course as well.
ANITA: Great.
Thank you.

Professor Chueh, do you have
some questions for Will?

This is going to be
fun, Will and Will.

Do you have some questions
that you would like to pose?
WILL CHUEH: Absolutely, Anita.

And it's great to be on stage
with you, Anita, and of course,
with Will.

You know, before I ask
Will some tough questions,

I just want to give everyone
a sense of the scale

and urgency of the
challenges confronting us
on energy and sustainability.

We have eight billion
people on Earth.

And whatever we do will
have to be delivered
to the entire population.

So that gives you a
sense of the scale.

In terms of the
energy transition,

estimates from Stanford
is now putting this

at approximately $70
trillion in total.

So this is a huge economic
opportunity for the world.
And then finally, the urgency.

The latest projections
are showing

if we don't alter the way
we use our energy today,

we only have about
seven more years

until we breach the 1.5 degree
Celsius temperature increase

and a little bit over 28 years
until we breach the 2 degree
Celsius temperature increase.

So this gives you a
sense of the scale

and the urgency of the
challenge in front of us.

So this is really
what we are trying

to tackle here at Stanford
across the entire university

and especially in the Doerr
School of Sustainability.

And in the Energy Innovation and
Emerging Technologies Program,

we're covering
many aspects of it.

And today, I'm really delighted
to talk to Will about water.

So, Will, you know, when
we think about water,

we think about maybe water
for drinking, water for food,

maybe also water for, say,
hydroelectric electricity
generation.

But water is a lot
more than that.

So I really want to pull
the threads out here a bit

and maybe firstly have
you talk more broadly,

what are some of these
connections between water, water
treatment, and also energy?

What is that connection
there that maybe

not everyone sees
from daily life?

WILL TARPEH: Yeah,
great question, Will.

There's some really fundamental
connections between water
systems and energy systems.

As you mentioned, water is
used a lot to produce energy,
as it were, and hydropower.

And that's maybe some of the
oldest incumbent technology

that connects or is a sinew
between water and energy.

We can also think
a lot about energy

in terms of the energy that
goes into treating water,

to producing drinkable
water, as it were.

And with that energy comes a
lot of greenhouse gas emissions

as well in terms of the
environmental context.

So some estimates put
nationwide in the US,

our wastewater treatment plants
are responsible for about 3%
of our total energy emissions.

So, of course, that's
a small percentage
but a huge number, right?

So just treating wastewater
so that we can emit it

and treating drinking water
so that we can drink it

costs us a lot of energy
and associated emissions.

So in any effort we can
take to lower the energy

input of treating water
is that's time well spent
in terms of these transitions.

Water is, of course, used a
lot in chemical manufacturing
as well.

So when we talk about
electrifying, manufacturing,

and reducing the environmental
impacts of manufacturing,

water is going to play
a huge role there,

especially because we often
discharge water from industry
into the environment.

And if there are ways to
capture value from that water,

we can reduce the total energy
input and emissions associated
with chemical manufacturing.

WILL CHUEH: So,
Will, you mentioned

that wastewater
treatment accounts

for 3% of our emission in
terms of carbon intensity
just for everyone else.

This really sort of is on
the same scale as aviation.

So when we think
about decarbonisation,

these three persons
really add up.

So aviation is a
huge carbon producer.

So likewise, from
Will's work, this

is also highlighting the
importance of wastewater.

So, Will, how are
these carbon generated,

the CO2s and the emissions
in the wastewater?

Is it from the energy
generation or is it

from direct byproduct
of water treatment?

How does it interact
with the environment?

WILL TARPEH: Yeah, when
we're treating water to drink

or treating wastewater to emit,
one of the biggest things we do

is we add a bunch of
oxygen to that water

to drive biological
processes that will consume
all of the dissolved carbon.

And, I mean, our ideal product
there is actually, believe it
or not, CO2.

And so that's where a
ton of direct emissions

come from water
treatment plants.

And also adding that oxygen
takes a lot of energy itself.

Aerating the wastewater or
water that we want to drink

can cost us around 50%
of the energy associated
with treating water.

You can also imagine
all of the pumping that

has to happen from
across a whole city,

for example, to pump millions
of gallons of wastewater

to one place costs
a lot of energy.

And so there's movements
to think about.

What does it look like to treat
water on site in a building

so you don't have to
transport it miles and miles
before it gets treated?

A third area where there's a lot
of energy involved in-- energy

and emissions, in particular,
involved in wastewater and water

treatment is actually
kind of hidden.

It's embedded in the chemicals
with the chemical inputs we use.

So if we add hydrogen peroxide
or if we add chlorine or add

an acid or base to
clean up our water,

if we think about that from a
lifecycle approach like what

went into producing those
chemical inputs that we're using

to clean the water,
we've seen examples

where something like
making sulfuric acid

can be 70% of the emissions,
the carbon emissions associated

with the specific
treatment process.

So it's kind of like
there's surface level

emissions, direct
emissions, and then

you have to dig all
the way down to,

we would call them
scope two or scope three

emissions associated with
water treatment as well.

WILL CHUEH: Wow, it's really
quite intense in terms

of the carbon footprint,
so the carbon footprint

of the energy needed
to treat the water,

the carbon footprint in
terms of the oxidized product

from treatment and
also the carbon

footprint of the chemicals
used in treating the water.

And that's what amounts to the
3%, Will, that you talk about.

What are some of the exciting
innovations, you know,

whether it's at the technology
level or at the systems level

that you are pursuing to
decrease these carbon footprint?

WILL TARPEH: Yeah, I
think even in addition

maybe just even before
decreasing them just
to track them.

I kind of laid out
what happens with CO2,

but we can also think
about methane emissions.

And increasingly, we're thinking
about N2O, nitrous oxide
emissions as well.

And believe it or not,
the answer, at least

of the experts I
know, myself included,

is we don't know how
much N2O is emitted

or methane is emitted
at treatment plant.

So there's a huge
movement right now

to just be able to
track these emissions

and so that we can get
the pieces of the pie

and know where we
should cut things down.

But in terms of
decreasing emissions,

so one aspect of decreasing
emissions is monitoring them.

So there's a need for these
high resolution sensors

to be able to measure these
directly from water treatment.

But some of the innovations
we're looking at

are just ways to establish
circularity, right?

If we can reuse an
acid or base or can

we generate it
electrochemically.

We're doing a lot of work kind
of taking electrolysers and fuel

cell type of
architectures and saying,

can we use those not just to
generate oxygen and hydrogen

or to use oxygen and hydrogen
to drive energy storage,

but can we actually use
those to treat the water

and replace chemicals
with electricity?

So we can produce acid and base
when we do water electrolysis?

Normally, those are
seen as byproducts

because you're
focused on the gas.

We sort of flip
that and say, let's

treat the gases as byproducts
and treat the protons

and hydroxide ions we make
as the real valuable product.

And if we have pH
gradients, then we

can start to do things like
regenerate ion exchange resins

that help us treat water or
we can wash reverse osmosis
membranes with acid and base.

So we can literally
just look all

around chemical manufacturing
and water treatment

in particular and say any
time you add an acid or base,

we can generate it on site
using electrochemical techniques

just using an
electrolyzer that's
adapted to water treatment.

So those are a
couple innovations
that we're working on right now.

But maybe more specifically in
terms of a circularity case,

we're doing a lot
of work these days

on trying to recycle lithium as
we think about ways to affect
chemical manufacturing.
And nitrogen is another case.

But we can talk about those
in more detail as we go.
WILL CHUEH: Thank you, Will.

This will be a great segue
for my next question.

But maybe one more question
on the current point.

You know, wastewater treatment
has been around for a long time.

Can you give us a sense of
the degree of innovation

that we have seen, say,
over the past 50 years?

Is this a field in which
technologies are constantly

being tried and
tested, or is this sort
of ripe for innovation?

Give us a sense of what is
the status of the innovations.

WILL TARPEH: Yeah, it's a
super interesting industry.

So, I mean, wastewater treatment
plants were generally most

of them built in the early 20th
century, so about 100 years ago.

And their main benefit was
reducing diarrheal disease.

So people were not experiencing
things like cholera or dysentery

in the US anymore or as
nearly as large an extent

because we were
chlorinating drinking water.
We were treating our wastewater.

And so the big
innovations have been

how do we remove pathogens,
disease-causing organisms

from our wastewater so that
they don't infect other people?

Then came along
innovations like how

do we get all of the
organic matter out.
And that's how we oxidize it.

And so then we've sort of kind
of like oil and gas refining,

we've started adding
on unit processes
to do additional things.

So now we're able
to treat nutrients
like nitrogen and phosphorus.

And we're able to treat
emerging contaminants.

You may have heard
of forever chemicals

like perfluorinated
chemicals that
are just being regulated now.

So it's kind of like
we keep adding on.

But in terms of
innovation, I think

the key innovation
areas right now

are we're used to
removing pollutants.
That makes a ton of sense.

And the key innovation
right now is can we

remove pollutants and do
something useful with them?

Can we remove and recover
them for some valuable input
elsewhere?

Right now if we think
about how much money we're

kind of flushing
down the drain, it's

in the order of
billions of dollars

if you think about the
dissolved chemicals that

are in wastewater that gets
emitted into the environment.

WILL CHUEH: So, Will,
this is a great segue.

So walk us through
a little bit how

these valuable chemicals entered
the wastewater to begin with.

So you mentioned lithium,
which is used in batteries.

You mentioned nitrogen.
You mentioned ammonia.

So just walk us through a
little bit about, you know,

what comes in and then what
do we want to concentrate out
of the wastewater?

WILL TARPEH: Yeah,
there are lots

of different types
of wastewaters, which

is kind of where we start on
step one of the or module one
of the course, this EIT course.

But broadly speaking,
if you think

about a household
or a business, think

about your house and
everything that you
do that goes down the drain.

There's going to be
nitrogen. There's
going to be phosphorus, carbon.
All of that can be recovered.

It's not recovered now, but
it can be reused, right?

The challenge is to be
able to separate it out

of the wastewater and make
something valuable from it.

Now, think about if you work at
an industrial company, right?

Say you're
manufacturing batteries,

there's going to be
battery scrap on the floor

that you're going to
have to get rid of.

You're going to use acids and
bases to leach or to precipitate
at different stages.

And you'll have some wastewater
that you generate as a company
that you will also send--

you will deem a waste and also
send to a wastewater treatment
plant.

So wastewater treatment plants
get these huge amalgamations,

mixtures of everything,
everyone's waste products,

and their job is to do the
equivalent of solids recycling

where you say, OK,
the plastics go here.

The metals go here,
this type of thing.

But you'd have to do that
with different elements.

There have been some estimates
looking at transition metals,

like we're talking like gold,
silver that's in wastewater

as well from the
medicines we take

or from mining
tailings, et cetera.

And this is also on the
order of tens of millions

of dollars that's deemed waste
simply because it's too dilute,

going back to the
Buckminster Fuller quote.

But if you can change
the concentration

or change its purity, then
we have a product again.

WILL CHUEH: Will, give us a
sense, you know, for every, say,

kilogram of batteries
I have to make,

or better yet, a
kilogram of battery I

have to recycle,
how much water do I
need to supply to that process?

Just give us an order
of magnitude estimation.

WILL TARPEH: Yeah, yeah,
for a kilogram of batteries,

you're looking at easily
hundreds of liters of water

or hundreds of liters
or gallons of water.

And so the water use is
something we've analyzed.

And it's an environmental
impact that we

don't look at as much
as, say, greenhouse gas
emissions or carbon intensity.
But it scales quite fast.

So if you think
about the scaling

curve we need for
lithium ion batteries

or let's just say
renewable batteries,

the scaling curve for
water is 100 times higher
in terms of liters needed.

And a challenge with that
is that across the world,

over 80% of wastewater
generated is not

even treated before it makes
its way to the environment.

So we're just letting it all
go, and then we're saying,
oh, we're scarce.
We need more lithium.

But we actually just let
it pass by because it

was in too dilute a stream
for us to consider valuable.

WILL CHUEH: Yeah, I mean,
this is a tremendous number,

Will, because if you consider
the amount of materials

we have to make, say, for
electric vehicles, all

of the utilization on
the order of mega tons,

a million ton per
year per material,

and then I think,
Will, you just told us

you would need,
you know, something

like 100 liter per kilogram,
so the amount of water use
is just tremendous.

And then you're
also now telling us

that in addition to
the water intensity,

there's also the issue of useful
and expensive elements, which

are dissolved in the water that
you will have to separate out.

And unlike recycling, you
couldn't just mechanically

isolate one type of
plastic from another.
There's no label.

There's only elements
and chemistry.

So maybe moving into that a
little bit more, so what--

give us a sense at
a high level, what

are people doing now to separate
the lithium from the cobalt,

and what can we do to make
that process more efficient,
less carbon intensive?

WILL TARPEH: Yeah,
a lot of the ways

that we're separating
out lithium and cobalt

have to do with
mining processes.

And it's interesting because
water is also used in mining.

And so you could
argue what we're

doing is kind of innovating on
mining processes as well, right?

And so in general, what
people are doing is

they usually break
this into three types
of recycling processes.

There's mechanical,
like you mentioned.

You need to separate the
battery parts if you're
starting with a spent battery.

There's hydrometallurgy where
you, like the name suggests,

you put it in water,
specifically acid,

and you leach out
all of the elements
and they dissolve in the water.

So that's where I spend
a lot of time thinking.

And then there's pyrometallurgy,
where you use energy, basically,

to pyrolize what's
in the batteries.

And so a lot of this
hydrometallurgical processing

is, in fact, exactly
what we do in my group.

It's taking a water
stream and saying,

how do I separate the
elements out here?

Broadly speaking,
what's done nowadays

is dissolving the water out, so
boiling the water off or trying
to precipitate a solid out.

What we're bringing to
this conversation is,

can we use water treatment
methods, if you will,

things like membranes
that are selective?

They let some ions through and
reject other ions or things

like adsorbents like
a filter bead that

does the same thing is selective
between different ions that

allows us to produce higher
value products while doing so
at lower energy inputs.

It takes a lot of
energy to boil water.

It takes a lot of energy to
remove a solid from a liquid
in terms of precipitating.

It can take less energy to just
flow water through a membrane

and get selectivity given the
features of that membrane.

So that's a lot of
our work these days.

WILL CHUEH: So this
would be a sort

of a souped up version
of water purifiers

we use in residential
applications.
WILL TARPEH: Yes, yeah.

So the analogy I make often
is it's like a Brita filter.

And if you've ever been
curious or accidentally

broken open a Brita
filter, you would
see a bunch of black beads.

We are designing
those black beads.

But rather than just take
everything out of the water,

we design them to
just take lithium

or just take cobalt
or just take nickel.

And if we do that,
then we can make

a really high
concentration, high purity

lithium stream or cobalt
stream or nickel stream later.

WILL CHUEH: Wow, Brita
filters for lithium,
sounds very exciting.

Will, we talked a little bit
about industrial applications

of wastewater and purification
to recover precious elements.

But how about agricultural
or residential applications?
You alluded to ammonia.

You know, talk us a little bit
about how fertilizers, you know,

residential great
water treatment,

how does this come
into the equation?

WILL TARPEH: Yeah, there's a lot
you can recover from wastewater.

One of the things I like
to say is the easiest thing

to recover from
wastewater is water.

And so one of the things
we can do from greywater,

think your shower, think
water besides toilet water

in your house, you can
recover water from that

because it's actually quite
dilute in other contaminants.

So we can put it through
something like reverse osmosis,

for example, and
get just water out.

And some people have those
types of recycling systems
on their properties.

In terms of nitrogen, that's
a fascinating case to us

because it contrasts a
lot of ways with lithium.

Lithium is an
economic case, right?
There's a drive for lithium.

But we don't yet know the
environmental consequences

of lithium discharges
into the environment.

But we know that most
people would say,

no, I want that
lithium, especially

if they happen to be related
to the battery industry at all.

Nitrogen is kind
of the opposite.

There's a bunch of environmental
data about algal blooms

and dead zones,
oxygen-limited zones

in water-based environments
that nitrogen can really
cause havoc for.

But there's not that
strong economic case yet.

And that's because we
have a wonderful way

of manufacturing fertilizers,
the Haber-Bosch process that's
cheap.

It's relatively
energy efficient,

but it also emits a
lot of CO2 in part

because of how we produce
hydrogen nowadays.

But in any case, what
we're trying to do

is use wastewater
from fertilizer,

fertilized fields, from
municipal wastewater,
from our homes.

And that contains a lot of
nitrogen. If you collected

all the fertilizer runoff and
all of the municipal wastewater

around the world, not an
easy task, but if you did it,

you could offset
around 25% to 30%

of all of the fertilizer
needs of the entire world.

So that's basically
where we're letting

a quarter of what the fertilizer
we need go down a drain
or go into waterways.

So we are designing
electrochemical techniques

to be able to select
just nitrogen out

of complex, real wastewaters
so that we can make fertilizer

on site, which can
also increase access
to fertilizer across the world.

WILL CHUEH: Will, you
touch upon circularity
briefly in all three cases.

Can you give us a
few examples maybe

sort of industrial and
residential examples

of where circularity
has been achieved,

which we don't have to make new
chemicals or mine new things

from the ground to sustain
our lifestyle, what are
some of the examples at work?
WILL TARPEH: Sure.

A great example is actually
going back to reverse osmosis.

So most of the time, we think
about making drinkable water

from seawater, which that's what
reverse osmosis membranes were
first designed for.

But over the past
several decades,

we've also been able
to do the same thing
but from municipal wastewater.

So there are several
installations of this.

One of the best known
is in Orange County
here in California.

But there's a wastewater
treatment plant, and right next

to it, a drinking
water treatment

plant that takes the
wastewater and turns it
into drinkable water.

And the regulations
are so strict on it.

But it leads to that
water that comes out

is cleaner than what comes out
of a drinking water treatment
plant.

So there a case of circularity
that works out really well.

Another example would
happen, actually,

in some of these mining
installations, right?

It's like you get some
tailings and then you say,

oh, let me recycle that
like make a recycle stream

and push it back through
and see if I can get more.

So we do this all
the time when we

have what's called single
pass conversion going

through a process and we say,
but if I turn it back and have

it go through multiple times,
I can get a higher efficiency
from it.

So an example of this is like
taking a nickel and cobalt

solution that's produced when
you're manufacturing batteries

and saying, let me get
that back because then I

can increase the purity of my
nickel and cobalt generation.

So there's a huge
case to be made here

in saying to
companies, hey, what

if I could get you some
of your precursor back?
Would you be interested in that?

And then you might not even have
to pay a wastewater treatment
plant to take it as well.

WILL CHUEH: Sounds like a
huge economic opportunity.

Another example I can think
of is lead acid batteries.

And virtually anyone who has
a car, even an electric car,
has lead acid batteries.

And there, I believe
we have close to 99%

recycling rate of lead, which
is hazardous for mining.

But now we don't have
to mine very much lead

because most of the
lead are circular.

In contrast, for
lithium ion batteries,

I think our recycling
rate are just around 1%.

So there's a lot of
room for improvement.

And I think there's the
promise of circularities

for a lot of these solutions
that we need for sustainability.

So we're coming to the
end of our time here.

I want to make sure we have
time to answer some questions.

So let me hand it
off back to Anita

to field a few questions
from our audience.
Anita.

ANITA: Yeah, we've
got some questions
coming in from the audience.

You kind of touched
on this, but maybe you

could go a little bit
further on the role of water

in chemical manufacturing,
specifically
of fertilizers and fuels.

And then I think what's
also fascinating about what

both of you are talking about
is the different disciplines

of professionals that are
needed in the entire supply

chain when we talk about
circular economies.

But if you could talk
about the role of water

in chemical manufacturing
a little bit

deeper with regards
to fertilizer

and how that fits into
the entire supply chain.
WILL TARPEH: Absolutely.

Yeah, so when it comes
to fertilizer production,

a fair number of fertilizers are
actually sold in liquid form,
right?

So they are dissolved in
water, and then a farmer

will take them and
dilute them further.

And so that water has to be
introduced into the fertilizer
production plant at some point.

Another example would be when
even solid fertilizers are

produced like urea or ammonium
phosphate, monoammonium

or diammonium
phosphate, they have

to be precipitated
out in some solution.
And that is usually water.

And so that water
is used and then

maybe discharged to a
wastewater treatment plant.

Another place that water is
involved, not necessarily

in fertilizer
manufacturing, but certainly

in the fertilizer
cycle is what we

call fertilizer or
agricultural runoff, which

is when it rains on
a fertilized field

and a lot of the
fertilizer that's not yet

taken up by plants goes into
rivers, streams and lakes.

In terms of the other
question about--

what was the other question,
Anita, about circularity?

I kind of missed
the second part.
ANITA: There we go.

You kind of described it
throughout the entire supply
chain.

WILL TARPEH: Yeah,
I think there are

opportunities for circularity
throughout the supply chain.

So one example is
one of my students

works a lot on these
lithium selective membranes.

And you could think about this
throughout the energy storage
supply chain, if you will.

So it could be in
the mining in terms

of can we use things
